comment: it is near my house so after a stress day I can know that I will always be welcome to this cheep bar the food is nice and if you want to watch the epl you can get a beer and bite while watching the match

rest_name: Moa Tiki New Zealand Bar and Grill CCP
address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-70/71 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: We are 4 at this restaurant at the moment for dinner and have received each dish in a sequence of 10 minutes difference ie the first person was served about 40 minutes ago while the 4th person is still not served!!!

rest_name: Moa Tiki New Zealand Bar and Grill CCP
address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-70/71 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: When you finally grow tired of "Asian Fusion" food or just want great grill food with even better service look no further.  The outside seating and music is perfect.

rest_name: Moa Tiki New Zealand Bar and Grill CCP
address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-70/71 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: Good cold craft beer, hot and crispy fish and chips, friendly service and a guy on guitar playing James Taylor and Cat Stevens. Best place I found in the fairly sterile business park area.

rest_name: Moa Tiki New Zealand Bar and Grill CCP
address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-70/71 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: Moa is a fun place to relax.  Busy after work.  Beers on tap are good.  Drink outside and watch people or inside.  Both are good.  They often have live music.Food is good.  I was impressed that my ceasar salad was cold, crisp, and even the croutons had crunch.Well done!

rest_name: Moa Tiki New Zealand Bar and Grill CCP
address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-70/71 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: we came into here during lunch on a friday, it was packed but we were able to get a seat.  the service was subpar, but to be expected with almost every table full.  i tried the bbq chicken salad and the buffalo bites.  it was nothing special.  my coworkers had the burger and it looked very large and pretty good.  i liked the fact that they had football on the TVs

rest_name: Moa Tiki New Zealand Bar and Grill CCP
address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-70/71 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: I liked my dinner here! Loved the environment, close to my hotel..loved the menu..the prices make sense. I got the sirloin and shrimp with mashed and veggies - they tasted very nice. I'd come back if I were here longer. The manager, mr. Andrew Wee, came by to greet me..and to give me an actual steak knife :-) Very kind of him! He asked how things were and left a very good impression. Definitely very good service and a great solution if you don't eat Asian food, like me.

rest_name: Moa Tiki New Zealand Bar and Grill CCP
address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-70/71 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: This is another average lunch destination in the Oasis area of Changi City Point Mall.Since it was lunch, I did not try any of their beers.  It is a micro-brewery.  So, their beer might raise their score.The service is straight-forward, friendly, and professional.   There were no hiccups in the flow of the meal or noticeable missteps in the service.The room is clean and neat.  It has that new restaurant feel.  I would not say it actually reflects any particular style.I had the fish and chips.  With the group I was dining with, this was a popular option.These were not too bad.  The fish was good. It might of been able to hold up in the fryer for another 30 seconds or so.  The breading was ever so slightly mushy on the inside.  But it was crisp on the outside.  I quite liked the fries.  The overall portion was a little smaller than traditional fish and chips.  i can not remember the exact price.  But I can remember it warranting a full portion.tinyurl.com/9kaf73lThe salad was small but very fresh and crisp with mixed greens.tinyurl.com/9ng7rboOverall, Moa is a basic lunch spot.  If you are at Changi and need lunch, it will do.  Personally, I think Caprilicious (inside the Capri hotel) is a better option than the three restaurants (Moa, Lavaedge, and Table Manners) that line up in Oasis @ Changi City Point.   But, you will find the service is good, the ambiance is clean and neat, and the food is relatively good.  Sometimes, that is all you need for lunch.

address: 1 Bedok Road #01-28, Bedok Food Centre Singapore 469572 Singapore
comment: There's a queue (but quite fast moving) in front of the stall. There's a picture of Lee Kuan Yew in front of their stall on their signboard. It says on their signboard that this stall is managed by Tong Fong Fatt. I don't know what that all means but the chicken rice is quite good. I had a plate of roasted chicken rice, and at $2.50 for the plate, it was pretty generous in portioning. The chicken was tasty and juicy. The rice was fragrant and not oily. I'll be back for more.

My mom and I love Song Fa, which is why we went twice within a week to their location in the Jewel.  Simple and hearty food.  What is there not to like?  Love the free refills of soup.  On my last visit, I was a bit tired of meat (been eating A LOT of local hawker food in the last two weeks), so we ended up sharing a bowl of BKT and ordering a bunch of sides: ngoh hiang (yes, more meat), dou maio, salted veggies, peanuts.  All delish and it was plenty.  They didn't have a problem with having us share one bowl of BKT either.  No wait both times we visited, but maybe that's because these were on weekdays.  Or is the Jewel always this empty?  Not that I'm complaining!

I've come to know of this dish through a food vlogger on YT. It was one of his favorite dishes so I thought it was worth giving it a try. Bak Ku Teh (Pork rib soup) is one of the signature dishes of Singapore. You'll find that breakfast is somewhat of a liberal concept here- - it goes beyond just pancakes and eggs. If it's served in the morning, there's no reason it can't be breakfast. No one will look twice as you're devouring a hearty bowl of pork ribs for your morning nourishment.PORK RIB SOUPThe soup was peppery, garlicky and served piping hot. The pork ribs were fall off the bone-tender. A side of Youtiao (Chinese Donut) is great for dipping into the broth after you've finished the ribs. While the soup had a good kick it was unfortunately, just ok. SPICY PORK BELLYBraised pork belly served in a clay pot was tender however, a bit dry and too sweet. I found the chili infused soy sauce helped balanced out the sweetness but didn't do much for the dish overall. If I'm being honest, this is a pass for me. While this particular meal wasn't anywhere near my favorite, the soup would be best eaten when it's cold out.

Excellent!  They even refill your pork ribs soup as much as you want.  Love the white pepper garlic broth.  Also got to try the dou mou which is a veggie I never had.  They cooked it well with fried shallots and lard and their special sauce.  I also enjoyed the drink.

address: 80 Airport Boulevard, Departure Transit Lounge Mezzanine Level 3 Changi Airport Terminal 1 Singapore 819642 Singapore
comment: I needed to eat lunch at the airport before flying out and I also needed to use up some Singaporean money I had left. I really wanted noodles and Peach Garden had such a cute name. They actually have several locations throughout the city. Their airport one is at terminal 1. Ween I arrived, it was still a kit early for lunch, so there weren't very many people. I was seated right away by a super nice woman. I ordered the prawn dumpling noodles (dry), an order of the siu mai, and a Chinese hot tea. The lady said the siu mai would take 10 minutes. My noodles were yummy - I thought they tasted good, especially for airport food! The dumplings were good and were full of shrimp - no skimping here! The siu mai came out in a steamer basket and was also tasty. The tea was good too. Oh and the wet towelette actually smelled like peaches! The chopsticks were fancy too. The lady who handled my bill was also super nice and courteous. Tasty food and excellent customer service!

address: 80 Airport Boulevard, Departure Transit Lounge Mezzanine Level 3 Changi Airport Terminal 1 Singapore 819642 Singapore
comment: A nice place to chill and enjoy some lighter fare before a flight.  I really appreciated the spacious seating and the carpeted area, which kept the place nice and quiet.  Service is efficient and it's sometimes better to have a light wonton noodle soup rather than downing a burger, fires and shake before a 6 hour flight.  It's a little on the pricey side, but worth it for an hour of peace and a warm meal before a flight.

address: 80 Airport Boulevard, Departure Transit Lounge Mezzanine Level 3 Changi Airport Terminal 1 Singapore 819642 Singapore
comment: Yay for an outpost of Peach Garden! And at the airport, no less. Had carrot cake (not bad), shrimp and chive dumplings (very full of shrimp! I guess for $4.20, one would expect it), and wonton mee (~$10 or so I think). The soup was delicious, wontons were okay (4 of them), mee was good.

address: 80 Airport Boulevard, Departure Transit Lounge Mezzanine Level 3 Changi Airport Terminal 1 Singapore 819642 Singapore
comment: They got some good noodle here and it is on the pricy side just because it is in the airport.   Personally I don't know what to order, so just order what look good and it taste damn good too.

address: 80 Airport Boulevard, Departure Transit Lounge Mezzanine Level 3 Changi Airport Terminal 1 Singapore 819642 Singapore
comment: Overall very good actually. Especially for airport food. I had the shrimp dumpling noodle soup, a side (3) of spinach prawn dumplings and tea for 20S$. Service was quick, attentive and the spinach dumplings were actually excellent. Again for airport food, great! Nothing was just sitting around. They made everything after I ordered it.

I. Want. To. East. Here. Every. Day. Amazing amazing amazing food. Wish there were more Din Tai Fungs in this world. It would be a better world if there were. Try the pork black truffle soup dumplings!!

Din Tai Fung is one of the heavyweights in the Dim Sum genre. Known the world over for their iconic Xiao Long Bao. My first experience here couldn't have gone any better. The food was great! It wasn't anything fancy but your classic dim sum dishes were done deliciously well. What really impressed me was the service. It was exceptional! I was beyond cold and one of the staffs went out of her way to lend me a shawl. I was grateful as it made my dining experience even better once I was able to stop shivering! After perusing the menu, we ordered the followings: Xiao Long Bao Prawn Pancake Pork Chop Fried Rice Steamed Chili Crab Buns XLB- These tiny pockets of dumplings loaded with tasty fillings infused in the fragrant broth were full of flavors. PRAWN PANCAKE- Deep fried prawns with a thin crispy exterior was tasty. PORK CHOP FRIED RICE- The pork chops were well seasoned over the fragrant rice was superb. STEAMED CHILI CRAB BUNS- The soft buns enveloping the chili crabs inside was just ok. Not something I'd recommend. Do stop by for your dim sum fix!

Wandering around and hungry after resting from our 16hr flight into town. Came across this place and menu looked good so we went in. The item which I hadn't experienced before was a little holder for my bag. It made for sitting at a little table better as I didn't have to balance my bag and I didn't have to hang it on the back of my chair. Clever. We ordered one of the steamed truffle and pork dumpling - a wee little thing which cost $5. I didn't want to order five in case we didn't enjoy it. My son chose the chicken dumplings. The food took a while to come and we were starving by then. The truffle dumpling was definitely worth it. I wish we had ordered more as it was better than the chicken dumplings. It features black truffles with fresh pork wrapped in the dumpling skin. And included rice broth in it so the liquid burst into your mouth when you bit into the dumpling. Delicious. We also had wontons and fried rice. Those were yummy too. Would go back next time we get a chance to visit Singapore.

Came here twice over the course of two weeks and once was amazing and similar to every other Singaporean DTF experience I've had, and the other must have been a very off day since many of our items, including xiao long bao and other dumplings, were served lukewarm.  In the latter case this was later in the night on a weekday so maybe that's why, but still doesn't make it totally acceptable.  Anyway, I typically love their xlb, pork chop fried rice, shrimp and pork dumplings, stir fried dou miao veggies.  10 minute wait on both occasions, probably because we were there both times on a weekday?  Kind of amazing given that any DTF in the US typically has a 1-2 hour wait.

This was my first time at any Din Tai Fung. The quality was obvious and everything was very good. We didn't have to wait for seating since we ate in Singapore and went at non busy times. If there were these in our town, I'd go often. I had their specialty but was most impressed with their pork bao bun. I didn't like the dan dan noodles. It tastes too formulaic and like it was just peanut butter mixed in. The quality of the plain chicken soup was amazing and I could taste the herbs in it.

A standard DTF outlet (what an abbreviation)! What's there to say - the best Xiao Long Bao around, plus a few other Chinese treats. This one is conveniently located directly at the T3 entrance of The Jewel on Singapore airport. A perfect place to have that quick stopover meal before or in between flights.

Quality is just as good as anywhere. Queuing is also not as long as expected about twenty minutes on weekends. Got the pork chop fried rice and the xiao long bao. Must come to jewel CHANGI airport, this is a fantastic place

I had always believed that Din Tai Fung service is always very good.  But after I had patron Jewel Din Tai Fung, the service level is not acceptable.  Waitress clear my table plates but did not do even say it politely and before I nod my head, she already took away all the plates.  Also, I asked for more ginger but to my surprise they told me a reason so lame that they said their supply is low at 4pm.

rest_name: The World is Flat at Changi Airport
opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: While Asia has some of the best airports in the world and Changi Airport is a jewel, airport bars have been often overlooked.  That has changed now that The World is Flat has opened in Terminal 1.  With staff from one of the best bars in Singapore, the selection of liquor and cocktails sets a new standard for what an airport bar can be.  Also having 10 taps of craft beer from Europe, Australia, the US, and even HK, doesn't hurt.   My go to drink here is the Manhattan, which uses some seriously good rye from the US and also uses some rosemary which works really well.  Definitely worth a detour and a nice treat before a flight!

What an incredible option for not only airport employees but the general public. This was my first meal in Singapore and it was an appropriate introduction to the hawker food scene. My friend and I walked past all the food stalls seeing what tickled our fancy which after 30 hours of traveling for me, was pretty much everything. My lunch was good and the price was even better.

address: 965 A Upper Changi Rd North Changi Garden Singapore 507667 Singapore
comment: Tucked away on a quiet street, this little cafe restaurant serves really awesome breakfast food. It has a very relaxed vibe to it. I could sit here all day reading a book, drinking cider (Brother's Toffee Apple cider is so tasty!) It is just across the Changi Women's Prison and you can hear bells at times. Gave me lots to think about just sitting there.They do lunch and dinner as well. The burger is pretty awesome. Love the juicy succulent patty that is contrasted by the sharp special sauce. My favorite has got to be their breakfasts though. I would compare the portion to Jones', slightly smaller but this is half the price of what you pay there. Value for money or what? Lots used to do meats so the sausages are good. Looks a bit on the thin side but it's juicy and fragrant. The blueberry pancakes are fluffy and moist on the inside and slightly crispy on the outside. I love the pancakes because they are not overly thick. I don't usually take pancakes because the taste gets boring after a while. Tried different pancakes from WH, Prive etc but i never liked them. FfT's is not bad but this is better. Go for blueberry, it's not as dry as the others.  The iced mocha is also one of the better ones i've had. I would put this after Jones' (or at the same spot). Thick, sweet and creamy chocolatey fattiness but i lurveeee it. This is a dessert in itself. I think they do a daily breakfast till 3pm.

address: 965 A Upper Changi Rd North Changi Garden Singapore 507667 Singapore
comment: Fantastic place for dinner (or a date night) in Singapore. It is a bit off the beaten track and difficult to reach by public transit, but well worth the effort. At the very eastern tip of the Island (about 15 mins east from Changi) this place serves up asian fusion twists on a variety of food. Their japanese grill is especially good and the meat is extremely well cooked and flavorful. Top marks for the ambience as well, which is very European overlooking the sea where you can enjoy a nice sunset sipping a cold beer.

address: 965 A Upper Changi Rd North Changi Garden Singapore 507667 Singapore
comment: Don't be deceived by their signboard - although they have painted 2 dogs on it, it's not actually a dog friendly cafe, which is a bit of a shame considering the cafe is in a very residential area.. would be great to be able to walk my dog here and grab brunch at the same time.Food here is excellent, everything is made well and with care. My personal favourites are their steak sandwich comes with a side of salad and fries, their blueberry pancakes (amazingly fluffy), and eggs hollandaise (which is only available on weekends and run out fast)! But the coffee is ordinary.. they don't have an option for skinny coffees (skim milk) which is a real reflection on their knowledge of coffees as we all know that the best coffee is made with hi-lo / skim milk.Also, service isn't always good - good if the place is empty, but once it gets crowded the staff can't seem to be able to cope, its almost impossible to get their attention for anything, and when we celebrated a birthday here once by wanting to share just ONE token cupcake between the 4 of us who all had ordered lunch, we were told by the waitress that we couldn't even after we told her it was a birthday and come on.. it was ONE cupcake, not an entire cake!  And they don't even offer cakes or cupcakes on their menu. Not impressed.

address: 965 A Upper Changi Rd North Changi Garden Singapore 507667 Singapore
comment: Amazing neighborhood place. Food is good and staff are really very nice. It would be great though if they can have a cover or umbrella for the counter dining outside so that pet owners who would like to sit there with pets will not be directly under the sun.

address: 965 A Upper Changi Rd North Changi Garden Singapore 507667 Singapore
comment: Came for brunch one Saturday afternoon with a friend who was raving about the place. The interior is beautifully decorated with a main chandelier piece and little pieces of interesting décor items here and there. I tried the Lots Breakfast, which was a heart English style breakfast. It was good but far from the best English breakfast. They served freshly squeezed juices, which was a plus. The burger was also good, but not extremely excellent. The cider menu is pretty extensive, so perhaps it would be a good place to chill in the evenings and get some good food, but I wouldn't come out of my way.

address: 965 A Upper Changi Rd North Changi Garden Singapore 507667 Singapore
comment: I used to live around the corner from this place and was a favorite of my wife and mine. Outstanding service. the staff are well trained and excellent. food is dynamite! we were regulars for Dinner and Breakfast. I have had most of the items on the menu. the burgers are great. steak is fabulous. full breaky (forgot what its called on the menu) super tasty. they serve great tea too from Gryphon its really nice. I got British Breakfast. great selection of craft beers from England and other parts. My wife used to always get either the green curry or beef stew.

address: 965 A Upper Changi Rd North Changi Garden Singapore 507667 Singapore
comment: I just moved to Flora Road and decided to walk around the corner and explore my new neighborhood and what did I find?  LOTS.  The menu is phenomenal but the taste is out or this world.  I have been back several times and everything I ordered was the best.  The house burger is great.  The chicken burger was awesome.  The breakfast menu is fabulous ( I had the eggs benedict).  My daughter ordered the Olio with Shrimp and she knows her pasta and she said it was as good as mine.  The service is fantastic.  A real hidden gem.  If you haven't tried it you are really missing something.

fantastic seafood and zi char at this casual chinese restaurant nearish the singapore expo - really, it's rather out of the way (for us), but it's now become my family's go-to place for crabs and the like, and well-worth travelling to. the place has been packed to the rafters even by early evening (we popped here on two consecutive sundays because it was so good) - but the prices are reasonable, the food is absolutely commendably executed, and service is both sincere and quick.having spent a few years away, I've gained newfound appreciation for places like this one - where you can viably decide not to cook and pay a little more for a balanced meal: this isn't really an option you often get in london - not such variety at equivalent prices, anyway.the food here is great - and it draws large crowds despite occupying two shop spaces in an obscure location, so I recommend reservations, and also that you head down for a spot of great seafood no matter where you are. it beats those too-crowded options at the east coast - you know which ones I mean - in price, service and quality.

KL hokkien mee, is not really there. Lacking the real charcoal fried taste Chili crab could be a tad bit spicy and add a hint of sugar... Crab meat is fresh. Stir fried Kangkong lack again the throughly stirred vegetable taste

Food standard fluctuates. Same dish can be delicious but bland on another visit. Lower your expectations and enjoy whatever is served.Wasabi prawns lack the heat.Nai bai claypot is unimpressive.KL hokkien mee is nothing to shout about.Crystal hor fun is almost tasteless.Salted egg crab is ok this visit. Very fresh.Deep fried prawns in beancurd skin is nice and fresh.Hotplate otah is nice.Tong po rou could be softer.Sambal kang kong is nice.
Restaurant name is changed to Phoenix Inn Restaurant.The popular hokkien prawn noodle is just ordinary.Over-priced in my opinion

My friends and I were on a quest for crabs and we googled for new places that we haven't checked out and read about this place call Big Eater Seafood. We decided to check it out as none of us have been there although it seemed to be a popular seafood restaurant in Simpang Bedok. They are super packed and even provide valet services as parking is limited here.I am very intrique by the wall of crab shells graffti that their customers have left behind. Tucked away in the east, we tried some of their popular dishes like the salted egg crabs and the KL hokkein mee, pretty yummy and we were not disappointed. Definitely worth coming back and checking out their other dishes. I love how the management at this chain restaurants name their chain stores pretty catchy. This particular one is call big eater seafood, they have the other outlets by the name of Grand Eater  and Master Crab.

Standard orders here are 1 x chili crab, 1 x salted egg yolk crab, 1 vegetable dish, and the not to be missed KL hokkien mee. BE is unusual in the sense that it's a largish, airy restaurant; quite unlike the crowded and claustrophobic settings with grumpy aunties that seem to be the norm at other seafood places. And surprisingly, the service is actually good. The aunties are friendly, and it's easy to catch their attention for advice (are we ordering too much??) and extra drinks. The crabs are firm and fresh, though the experts will tell you not to order when the moon is full or something like that. The salted egg yolk crab is better than the chili, while he KL hokkien mee is a happy heart attack on a plate; a mess of black stringy noodles and liberally sprinkled with lard. Oh so good. Prices are ok, and have been correspondingly adjusted for inflation, much to the the dismay of customers. There's valet parking too, which is a good option due to limited lots.

These days the trend is an increase in price with a decrease in nice. Unfortunately, the trend has hit Big Eater. While they still serve up a mean salted egg crab, the rest of the menu leaves a lot to be desired.  The seafood they served previously used to be one of the freshest around. The crabs were meaty and juicy, but these days they seem to have gotten considerably smaller.Bad points aside, the dried chilli frog is pretty decent, along with their signature KL hokkien mee. These are worth trying but I doubt its going to be enough to warrant a second visit.

Big Eater is popular seafood restaurant near Simpang Bedok. It is constantly packed with people, especially on weekends. I love their Malaysia styled fried Hokkien Mee (dark sauce!!!). On some days, the noodles seem to be too overloaded with lard. But usually, it should be fine. They are also known for their Seafood Crystal Horfun, which is cooked with generous portions of fresh seafood. The deep fried beancurd skin is also worth a try! Fresh seafood wrapped with beancurd skin. Although sometimes the wait can really be long (be prepared to wait up to 20 minutes on packed days!), I like that the seafood they use is really fresh and they give generous portions. Last but not least, I think they need to space out the place a little more. It can get really noisy when the restaurant's packed with people.

Big eater is a very popular eatery that services Chinese, Zi Char, Fujian, Seafood,  and Cantonese food. It is a corner store that takes up 2 units. The chili crab is delicious and so is the hokkien mee. Against my will I have been dragged here several times, but the food doesn't stop to surprise me. What erks me about this restaurant is the congestion and noise. They obviously are maximizing space with the amounts of tables set up. I wouldn't say much about the atmosphere, I wouldn't even give it more than one star, but the real reason why this place is so packed is because of the quality of the food.The service is constantly busy and is a task just trying to waive one down. The prices are reasonable, very satisfactory for the great food they serve!

rest_name: Chicken Rice & Roasted Meat Stall Koufu Food Court
address: Block 258 Pasir Ris Street 21 #02-313 Loyang Point Singapore 510258 Singapore
comment: Besides the delicious Chicken Rice, you can also have Noodles instead of rice.Do try the Chicken Cutlet Rice, yummilicious !!!

rest_name: Chicken Rice & Roasted Meat Stall Koufu Food Court
address: Block 258 Pasir Ris Street 21 #02-313 Loyang Point Singapore 510258 Singapore
comment: The Chicken Rice here is amazing. Great texture and for $3.50, you get everything - rice, soup and meat. All you gotta do is add $2 more and you get veggies! Which is perfect, as it makes me feel less guilty for eating Chicken Rice. :PWhat I Love: Although I've lived here for a long time - I've never really explored the Chicken Rice - a friend introduced me to it and I was blown away! Like literally! The rice is tasty, moist, the Chicken is full of flavor, the soup is good (which is very important to me) and they don't just sell Chicken Rice, you can get Char Siew Rice, Fried Chicken Cutlet Rice, or noodles even. I LOVE their Thai Style Fried Tofu, Cooked Veggies and Bean Sprouts. Usually, I get these tiny eats and stuff myself. I didn't realise how famous they were - but I think they deserve the fame and their reputation!What I Don't Love: Absolutely nothing!! ;D

rest_name: Chicken Rice & Roasted Meat Stall Koufu Food Court
address: Block 258 Pasir Ris Street 21 #02-313 Loyang Point Singapore 510258 Singapore
comment: This stall inside the Koufu foodcourt in Loyang Point is by far my favourite chicken rice store in the east.  For $3.50, the portions are incredibly generous - just as I was getting accustomed to chicken rice in foodcourts being basically rice with afew strands of chicken, I discovered this store that actually gives a generous portion of chicken! This explains the long lines that snake past the store every lunchtime on the weekdays and throughout the day on the weekends - I would say that they are un-rivalled in the east. Although always busy, the owners take the time to get every order perfect, with give you the part of the chicken that you prefer if it is available. As it is a small store with only 2 or 3 people working in it, and with a high demand, prepare to wait for your chicken rice - I had to wait in line for about 20 minutes the last time I went, but it was worth it :)

rest_name: The Asian Kitchen - Changi City Point Mall
address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-43 Changi City Point Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: This tiny restaurant does not have many tables and has narrow walkway, but it clean and new.Food is OK. I tried their roasted chicken with rice ($9) and it wasnt too bad. Chicken wasnt too dry and the salt/seasoning on the side goes really well with the chicken & rice. Drinks are self-service where they give you a cup and you help yourself from the soda dispenser. (No free refill)

rest_name: The Asian Kitchen - Changi City Point Mall
address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-43 Changi City Point Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: This is a review of lunch at The Asian Kitchen in Changi City Point Mall.  Actually, it is a review of an amalgamation of two trips there.You place the order at the counter and pick up your food.  I do think with the layout of the restaurant that true table service would work better.The staff is rather terse but professional.The ambiance is clean, new, and functional.  As a whole the food ranged from good to very good.  It was also nicely presented.  However, none of the dishes particularly stand out.  They are simple, straight-forward and well executed.Beef Stew - This dish was hearty.  It could maybe have used a touch more seasoning but I enjoyed it.  The meat was tender.tinyurl.com/9f8mto2Pork Dish - I apologize that I do not know the official name for this dish.  I did not order it.  It was a very good though.   The pork was tender with a nice little crisp on the outer edges.Roast Chicken - This is another dish that I enjoyed.  Once again, the meat was tender.  This dish could have also used a little bit more seasoning.tinyurl.com/9zlun8wCrispy Wontons - I pretty much had these to myself.  They made a nice little snack and the crispiness was a nice addition to the textures of the meal.tinyurl.com/8nz2sczThe bottom-line is that this is a decent option for lunch.  That is, if you work in the area or are shopping in the mall.  It is not a destination restaurant.  But, they do have decent food and a comfortable environment to consume it in.

rest_name: The Asian Kitchen - Changi City Point Mall
address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-43 Changi City Point Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: Food is very enjoyable and reasonably priced, if you don't speak chinese, your order will go wrong (and I go there about once a week). Too bad the service is not at the level of the food.The tables are also food court standard in terms of cleanliness :-/

rest_name: The Asian Kitchen - Changi City Point Mall
address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-43 Changi City Point Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: Ok well I'm coming from china so my standards are pretty high. Even street food has a bottom level quality. Roast chicken was ok but others are pretty low quality food.

opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: Not sure why the overall rating for this place is so low. I was like a kid at Disney's when I saw this food court!To start off, you have to go to the cashier line by the escalator to get a food card and load money on there before you can purchase any food here (Burger King is the exception). They have so many different stalls that offer at least 4-25 or so options each. It took me a long time to decide and I didn't even get the chance to check out everything.Saw the noodle soup and my eyes got fixated. I had the combination noodle soup, with a side of fried jumbo fish ball. The food looks better than it tastes. The noodle soup could use more salt, and the fish ball could use a better dipping sauce too. Overall, I was a little disappointed, but still enjoyed the food. The biggest win was the freshly juiced mango and guava cup that I had. It was so good I would have gotten another one (and try more food) if I wasn't already running late for my connection flight.Overall, don't let the overall rating scare you off. They have a lot of food selection here for very decent price. Give them a try while waiting on your next flight!

opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: love singapore, love changi airport. Avoid this food court at all costs, especially Ah Huat Chicken Rice. If the servers don't like something about you or if you ask for something (like not a bone on rice - should be chicken rice not bone rice), you're likely to get cursed in Chinese. Another dish, the chicken was raw and they refused to cook more, so was trashed. Complained to Changi Airport, and wrote a review on Google which got nixed (what the heck! shame Google for bowing to the owners and ad revenue). Note other people have said the same especially the rudeness. Changi needs to shuts this horrible experience down.

opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: Convenient  but dispiriting  selection . There's  so much  tasty food in SG but these were not tempting. Mainly "hawker style" but definitely  non-spicy and lacking vegetarian  options. At the stalls,  options  were further limited as food sold out. Place the order with  the  server, then go to a cashier  booth to make a payment.  You will  be  issued  with  a  card. Give the card to the server.Just remember  to  bring  your own serviettes.  None of that  here!!!Was so sad they ran out of dhal. The sambar was shockingly  bland. T_T

opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: It's my first time here and I read mixed reviews about the food and recently complaints about the poor quality of the food, so I decided to find out for myself. When you reach the entrance of the food court, there are a couple of sign boards that tells you to purchase a card as the stalls doesn't accept cash payment. Doesn't make sense for foreigners and in fact it's inconvenient. Why? You have to queue up twice - to purchase the card and seek a refund for it (or you can keep it), but for those who don't like collecting cards, refunding it for cash is probably the option. Why not allow cash payment at the counters instead? The prices of the food are overpriced, but what do you expect at airports, it's usually like that everywhere. I had the chicken rice ($6.50) and it's average, not really to my liking. For those on stop-overs, it's good to have a taste of Singaporean food, I guess that's the purpose of this food court. Don't expect much from the quality but at least you get to enjoy what's Singapore famous for - food! I will probably return to try other food. For good local food, check out other places.

opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: Singapore Food Street is basically everything I love about Singapore, namely the food scene, just at the airport. I've spent more time than I care to think about in the Singapore airport, and in general, this is my favorite place to get something to eat. There are a lot of different types of food here, so if you're with a group or family, you don't all have to get the same thing. They have breakfast options, as well as late-night food, especially since some of the stalls here are 24 hours. And naturally, there is a Burger King if you need that dose of Western food.There's a large area to sit behind Singapore Food Street, as well as more lounge chairs and a "snooze zone."Of course it all depends on where your flight is, because if you have a flight in Terminal 2, there's no real point in coming over here. But this is a good option in Terminal 3!

opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: This is much closer to street food than I expected but the payment system is weird where you have to queue up for a card  with the receipt before you can get the food. Food itelf was pretty good so suggest you try it

opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: It's been three months, and I can still remember the horrible experience I had at this place. And it's difficult to put my customer service experience into context because it didn't actually exist.I was ignored by the server-cashiers for as long as they could ignore me, and when they finally decided to acknowledge my presence, they appeared noticeably bothered. I condoned their behaviour because it was very early in the morning, which meant my choices were limited, and my nearest option was Burger King. (I don't eat at Burger King.)The food tasted bland, as though it'd been missing something, and the serving was rather small. Here's a tip: Arrive at the airport early, and walk to the next terminal if you have to. Do not eat here. You'll regret it if you do.

opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: If you have a red eye layover most of the places aren't open.  The ones that are have fairly mediocre food.  But maybe I just don't like Singaporean style food.

opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: Don't even bother. If you have time to stay in Singapore for a couple days, make your way to a real hawker center.You have to stand in one line to load a card with money.  The vendors only take the Singapore Food Street gift card payment.  You basically have to walk up and down the line of booths, decide what you want to eat, add up the price, and then stand in line to load your card. If you load too much money, they'll give refunds, but only in SGD.  The one thing I wanted, which was Hainan chicken rice, was CLOSED.  Sad face.  I settled for the roast duck and roast pork plate and shared the combination dry noodle with with my friend.  The food looks so amazing in the photos, but were pathetic when they served the dish on the counter.  The portions were only 50% of what was pictured and the quality left more to be desired. If you're laying over in the airport and are super desperate to get a taste of Singapore food, I guessssss you could eat here.  Otherwise, stay away.

opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: FOODSTREET Changi Airport Singapore, Terminal 3, could well be the most amazing street of food you may ever visit.  It is located upstairs in terminal three, in a single row of around one hundred meters. There are approximately twenty food stalls, all preparing as you wait, over 200 assorted Asian plates. The range of freshly prepared dishes In its self is difficult to fully comprehend. Prices are from around $15 to $1 per dish. We sat down to two very well prepared meals, while hundreds of people filed past ordering. As we were flying Singapore Airlines, we were given as a bonus four $20 vouchers, where half could be used for food, and the other half in any duty free shop at the airport.  Great value, quite understandable it being so popular. With vouchers fantastic value, "FREE"

A simple, homely cafe with pretty decor and food! While the space on the first floor may seem a bit cramped at first glance, the seating on the 2nd floor makes up for it and is a good place to leisurely enjoy your meal.Ordered the lunch special (available for a limited time only) which allowed us a choice of a large range of pasta for $8 only. I had the pulled duck macaroni which was made with 3 different types of cheese. Satisfying but a bit filling for one given the generous amounts of cheese heaped on the macaroni. My partner had the salted egg yolk pasta, which was cutely served in a jar. Didn't try it but she enjoyed it. Both our meals were served with a small side salad that was drizzled with wasabi teriyaki sauce. Couldn't appreciate the peculiar flavour but to each his own! :)Topped up $2 for earl grey tea and $5 for a jar cake

So I've seen the deals on QOO10 and I always wanted to try out this place, however, being situated at the EXPO means it's on one corner of the country that I rarely visit. Headed to SITEX and decided to check it out too.. read that Fart Tartz was located near coffee bean, and silly me didn't know that there were two coffee beans at the EXPO. It's not the first coffee bean you see near the MRT station entrance to EXPO, it's on the second floor on the adjacent wing of SITEX.. lol.. walk till your feet hurt past like HALLS.4.5.6... blah blah.. 9.... and you will see a starhub business center and take the escalators up .. and TA DA!! YOU WILL SEE ANOTHER COFFEE BEAN!! and right next to it, fart tartz cafe!! :) It is a cute cafe, with sofa seats, high bar counter top seats too.. and the bloom tarts :D They're soo cute, although they looked bigger on photos, they're actually palm sized. We ordered a matcha and a oreo nutella one, based on the shops' recommendation. at $5.50 nett, I can't complain too much. It was fun to cam whore with the "potted plants" and you get to keep the fake flower.. hurray for my mother! and we dug in!! :) the matcha was light and you could still taste the green tea flavour. The oreo nutella was a winner, I mean.. who doesn't like nutella? it's a winner on it's own.. at the bottom of the flower pot, there is a an actual chunk of the oreo, with the cream filling.. :) all in all a nice treat.. although I wouldn't bother taking 1hr 40 mins worth of train rides just for this.. but if you are in the area, do give it a try!

This place is the literal definition of heaven for durian lovers! I've been eyeing on this place for a few weeks prior to my arrival. It is located on the basement floor of Changi's Jewel in terminal 3. The server was amiable and helped to give me some suggestions on what to get.*Durian Charcoal PizzaWho knew sweet durian and salty cheese could be a match made in heaven? Best to share with a friend, or maybe just have it all for yourself? ;)*Durian Cake SliceEvery single layer is so flavorful! The cake was so moist and complemented well by the fresh durian cream. I would definitely buy the whole cake if I could! *Durian Ice CreamThis is the real deal! A big sign was put up there stating that it's a "die die must try" item. Ugh I mean, how can I just leave without trying it? It comes in two sizes: medium sized pint or small pint. I went with the latter. Wow, my mind was blown away! It was so velvety and rich! You could really taste the durian dancing on your taste bud! A must try indeed! I kept thinking to myself that I should've gotten the bigger pint. Oh well, next time! They also have different durian-inspired offerings such as durian hot pot (yes, for real), durian pancake, durian spring rolls, and many more! If you're looking for gifts to bring home, they sell different durian products (chips, dried durian, kaya jam, candies, cookies, etc.)I would definitely recommend this place to durian lovers out there! Great food and service, I will absolutely visit again if I'm in the area!!!

This review is for their fresh durian service. And yes! they have whole fresh durian available in the mall for you to select and then they'll open it and serve it to you. I personally selected a Mou Shan Wang (musang king) durian. Since I prefer the bitter flavor of durian instead of the sweet durian, I asked if I could smell it upon opening before being served to which the staff allowed me to do so. Awesome!! The durian was amazing and for the price paid, it was reasonable considering the quality and also where I'm eating it.

address: 1 Expo Drive #01-53, Hall 5 Atrium, Singapore EXPO Singapore 486150 Singapore
comment: Visited the store yesterday. My comments:Noodles-got the dry "u-moan", good texture. Noodle flavor--good flavor, just a little too sweet. Not strong vinegar flavor.Ingredients--good amount of ingredients. No vinegared mushrooms though compared to the bak chor Mee at Changi Point Mall. Soup--good flavor.Overall--good and can go again.

address: 1 Expo Drive #01-53, Hall 5 Atrium, Singapore EXPO Singapore 486150 Singapore
comment: Finding myself in Expo several times, my soup-loving-noodle-fanatic-friend recommended that I try this particular stall [one of few branches of the original] inside the Expo Universal Dining [or whatever they feel like calling their "Kopitiam"]. If there is one person I'd trust with noodle soups of any form, it'd be her. She is to noodles as I am to authentic Filipino food. Her cravings for noodles...is as demonic as my cravings for Pampangan Sisig. So I was game. I caved in and followed her even though the last 20+ times I've had any bak chor mee out and about had been a sheer disappointment that made me ask..."where the bloody hell did all the good *shi-fu-level-peeps* go?"She insisted on ordering for me and made me sit like a little bish at the only table available in another overcrowded part of Singapore [surprise...surprise]. She is an older sister to me so I have to listen...I have to obey. But guess what? I skipped being part of a 30+ minute line. These motherfarters are slow at 1930 hrs. Really slow. She was probably 10th in line...but 30 minutes before she got to order and FOR NOODLES??? You've got to be bloody joking! I was watching the line with my 20/20 vision and [confirmed with her later] that the "cook" was replenishing his ingredients at his own sweet time. I did see right after all!Yet, let's put it this way.That farter is alive and still cooking in hungry Singapore because what he brought out...was indeed worth the $4'ish dollars we paid per bowl. He's alive because the liver and minced pork brought loving flavors and a soup so hearty [from hundreds of plunged-to-cook-pork] that it made my heart slow down. He's alive because the freaking noodles seduced my tongue with each nibble and returned my need for bak chor mee in Singapore. He's alive...well...because people forget his snail-act the moment they plow into his food.So they are obviously not close to perfect [and probably brought some shame into the original which I now have to try]...but I'm still a fan because I'd eat this 30-minute-line-bowl-of-bak-chor-mee any freaking given day of my life here in Singapore. I shudder to think what I'd do for the original stall once I get to try it this week.

The roast pork is much better than the honey version for my taste, and is generally better (crispy skin and the meat is not too dry) than the average roasted meat stalls at hawker centers or coffee shops. A complete meal to go wtih the flavored rice. Good if they can increase the selection of beverage as it's quite limited now..

Pretty delicious pork and crackling although I did find a few pieces of the roast pork to be a bit on the drier side. I also don't like the little loose white tips of the ribs in the meat (I don't like biting into surprise bone bits). But the flavor profile was right on and really satisfied my taste buds. I asked the manager if the roast pork was a filipino inspired lechon but was quickly corrected to say that it was an originally developed recipe and different from lechon -- okay...Overall, service was very nice and attentive. Sides offered are roast potatoes, lemongrass rice (highly recommend) and garlic mash spuds. There were 3 little cups of sauces for dipping the pork. I thought the portions were pretty generous for the what we paid. Give them a try!

After passing by this basement stall so many times, my curiosity gave in and I decided to try their roast.You get a choice of original or honey, and you can either order it on it's own or in a combo with sides such as mashed potatoes.The roast itself was pretty tasty. I loved how crunchy and fatty it was. I don't know if I was lucky or if it's always like this, but I didn't have to deal with any bones in my portion- a lovely surprise! There are also 3 sauces you can play around with. There's a bottle each of spicy mustard and apple sauce that you can help yourself to, and when they deliver your order they give you a side of gravy. I thought all of them were good, but if I had to choose I'd go with the spicy mustard!The small portion starts at $8, and the meals can go up to $20 depending on how fancy you want to get. Unique option in the I12 basement, and I'm a fan! :)

Keith Crackling Roast has an original shop at Pasar Bella @ The Grandstand at Turf Club Road. This is their 2nd branch which opened in June 2015. Advertised as "the best crackling pork roast on the island", they serve up VERY crispy crackling roast & also juicy honey roast pork. A one person meal for lunch is S$11 which has both the meats, fragrant rice & some sliced cucumbers. A drink of your choice is included such as canned drinks, bottled mineral water, and syrup cordials (mango, calamansi). You help yourself with the cutlery and sauces (apple sauce or honey mustard). Personally I prefer the honey mustard to go with the meats to give it some kick.

I'm stuck at Changi for 10 hours, unable to leave the airport due to the coronavirus quarantine mandates. Soo, Of course I proceed to wander around the airport, something I never get the chance to do. Low and behold, there are several bee Cheng Hiang kiosks around the airport. You don't need to actually go into Singapore through immigration to get some delicious pork jerky. Bee Cheng Hiang has been around forever. Well, it's been around since 1933, according to the bag. All I know is that there was a Bee Cheng Hiang downstairs from my uncle's office on orchard and when I was little, I would sometimes get a pork jerky treat if I was good. Lol.They always give samples, and they sell most of the displayed items by the pound. They also sell some pretty decent pineapple tarts and crispy shrimp roll snacks, and those, I believe you can take into the US. Yeahhhh probably don't take the pork jerky in, but the pineapple tarts are an ok alternative gift to bring home.

Free samples and once you have sampled you will likely buy!  Keep in mind that you can not bring back any of the Beef Jerky to the States.  Thus, you'll need to eat it all on the flight home.If you try to sneak it in the States, the Agricultural Dogs will sniff you out and your expensive Beef Jerky will be confiscated and destroyed.  Trust me, I have witnessed this first hand.. albeit not me.  As for the Jerky, We tried three: the Golden Coin (a thicker chewy coin size piece of Jerky), the Regular ( Sweet Sticky), and the Spicy (Sweet, Sticky and a "little" Spicy).  We liked the Spicy one over all of the others.

My mother, many years ago, brought the asian-style jerky back to America, where it was promptly thrown away by Customs.  Many years later, when her son brought some of the vaccum-sealed packs (referred to by the other reviewer), he made sure her lesson was not wasted.  Whether you declare to US Customs is up to you - what you do there will determine whether these treats reach your loved ones. :-)

I am an avid jerky maker and sometimes eater. This hokkien style chinese jerky one of the favorite types  to eat. Bee Cheng Hiang mastered this broiled meat  candy for many to enjoy. You can order half and half 600g or 1kg. I got 300g each of the regular and spicy pork. Delish!

Their Pork Jerky is simply TO DIE FOR!!! After trying some of the fresh jerky, I was told by the cashier that only the vacuum-sealed packs we're allowed to the USA.  Upon arrival into U.S. Customs, it was confiscated due the category of being a "meat candy."  Needless to say, I was quite depressed for the loss of $50USD worth of product I was hoping to share with family and friends at home.
Grate place to hand out with friends nice coffee and breakfast for the family and kids

No real reason to go here other than curiosity. I'll pretend I'm checking on the quality, even though no one asked me to :)This location is pretty big considering it's in a public area of the airport (before security). The food is the same menu you expect in the US, except for this Pandan shake which I didn't try (sounded too sweet). The crinkle fries are crisp as expected so no complaints there. Price... well, it's at an airport and its a shake shack, so more than one should reasonably pay for a burger.

One day, I decided to drop by Jewel Changi Airport for some space, peace and quiet...and decided top drop by Shake Shack for some burger craving.LOCATION & AMBIENCELocated on level 2 of Jewel Changi Airport. If you are not sure, look for the Apple store or the Muji store, and you will find Shake Shack about 50m away. There used to be horrendous 1-2 hr queues when it first opened. But now, you should be able to get to place your order within 5 to 30 minutes of joining the queue of hungry patrons.SERVICEWith the covid-19 social distancing measures, the only service you experience is when you're queuing to get in and also when you are making your order at the cashier. Other than that, there is no other interaction with the staff. Good and bad perhaps. There is a self service automated hand washing machine around the middle of the restaurant, so that's as close as you get to somone washing your hands for you.FOOD & DRINKSThe special item in Singapore is the Pandan Shake. Just reading the item on the menu gave me a toothache. I might give it a try one day when I need a sugar rush...one day. The Hamburger feels a bit over priced at $7.50 for a basic item. The meat free Shroom Burger ($10.80) is quite good too with a light crispy mushroom patty.Personal favourite items are the crinkle cut fries and Shack Burger ($9.20 single & $14.40 for the double). Will need to try the other items one day....one day.COSTPrices are towards the upper end of burger joints. Hopefully the prices will come down one day...one day.

Above average American food. All the fuss and long lines... I don't know why? Tried once and that's it. The person who took the order was kinda rude. No expression, no smile, no suggestions. Made me feel not welcomed. The burger was ok, just a plain piece of beef between 2 buns. The taste was....? and a small cup for for a large lemonade. Looks like a medium sized drink in McDonald's. The fuss is only in the name. A famous American brand making local inroads. Time will tell and it might just fizzle out.

Pro tip: - wait times on weekends and weekday lunch rush can be up to 1 hour. Other times it can be less than 15 mins. - If you love bacon, HIGHLY RECOMMEND the Smoke Shack. - Manage your expectations when visiting Shake Shack. It's one of the best fast food burger chains in the world imo but it's not comparable to local burger restaurants like Mr Potato Head etc. No two burger companies are the same so make sure you don't fall into the trap of comparing this with another chain. Having said that the Shake shack hype is real. I was first hooked on their burgers since visiting their original location in New York. The location here in the Jewel mall is about 95% to the original. While the beef patty itself is average, what really makes this burger standout is the overall quality ingredients including the burger bun, secret sauce, cheese, and bacon. Highly recommend the Smoke Shack which includes the cheese, bacon, and red peppers. Regarding the wait time. If you go during their peak times (weekends all day & weekdays lunch rush) you could wait up to an 1 hour. For  off peak times less than 15 mins.

Had some time to kill before my flight home and saw it was open during circuit breaker, so thought why not and came here. I did not have too long of a wait since it was mostly just delivery people. The uniquely Singaporean menu item is the pandan shake, which didn't disappoint. It was a sweet treat before a bittersweet goodbye to Singapore

It is my first time at this 1st Shake Shack after it opens it's door more than year ago.  Guess the hype is gone now as the queue was less than 10 mins wait. So I got the smoke shack, milk shakes - peanut butter and the festive shakes, cheesy fries and concretes Shack Attack. The Smoke Shack was with bacon. I was disappointed with the bacon as it was tough not the crispy type. My fellow diners whom had the same felt the same disappointment. You imagine trying to eat some bark, that's what the applewood bacon was like - they must have removed the Apple and left the wood there. Minus 1  . The burger was not put together properly as in you do not get the cherry peppers evenly spread. So in one of my bite I took all the peppers, that was very spicy. Minus 1  for badly put together burger. The holiday cookie shake was like a sugar frozen yogurt. It was totally overly horribly sweet yogurt until the cookie crumbs that was only at the bottom 3 mm of the shake and you get the few cookie crumbs. It would be much better if there were more cookies crumbs. Minus 1 I easily found a table upstairs but as usual the normal locals here don't clean up their mess. There was like 4 staff standing waiting to wipe the tables but do not help clearing the table. They did not even help open the trash box flap when I took all the trash there. Standing like a block of wood.  Sure it is Boxing Day but you choose to come back to work, so get working. However they did wiped off the table. Minus 1 Ok something good must be said here, otherwise I run out of  and I have not even talk about the weird tables/chairs layout. The peanut butter shake was good, not the best or like those in US but for local establishment it is good. Overall the food seems over rated. Or may the hype just too much that I expected perfect food. It is just a so so establishment. I probably go there for the shake again and not the burger.

For an American burger place, I was half expecting big fat juicy burgers and a 1L coke for everyone. None of that for Shake Shack. For once, this burger place, on a morning 10.30am crowd, feels a bit like a club, a gathering place, a temple, like an Apple store in the past, of sorts.Yes, this might be a club for burgers and milkshake, much like the Apple store just a few feet away is to a haven for technology.If you wanna have brunch, come in before 10.30am and the queue won't be so bad. We waited for only about 20 mins (queueing and waiting for food altogether) and we were very lucky to have a seat very quickly. We finished our brunch at around 11am.The burger is really like totally opposite of what I used to love - Carl's Junior. None of that messy, cheesy, huge big fat patty. Its packaging may not seem big but it's filling for me (I ordered the single patty). I saw many people actually ordering the double patty. The bun was really high quality, the vegetables fit in just well, not too much and not too little. The patty supposedly tastes higher quality as well. Overall its a premium package burger. Some people might not be impressed as there is no 'kick' or 'wow' factor right off the bat. But when you bite into that clean non-messy-at-all burger and you remembered those days when your jeans had all that spilt sauce from your burger, you might appreciate this experience better. For me, I'd choose this any day. Yes some may say this is expensive. But I like that there is no silly convulated pricing and you do get the quality through in the burger and the milkeshakes, where I suppose shackburger and shakes is where its name derives from.Being impressed I'd give this a 4.5/5.+5 is from their quality, cleanliness, atmosphere, smiley service crew, good shackburger, milkshakes and drinks. You leave feeling good.-0.5 is from overtly-salty fries, not much option on condiments (only ketchup and mustard) and also price could be a bit prohibitive for some.

I feel like Shake Shack is a hype. I came here because some of my friends said it was the in n out of the east coast. Some of my friends told me it was better than in n out. I was honestly pretty disappointed.I ordered the Shroom Burger and fries and I thought it was okay. It didn't taste bad but the taste got boring after awhile. It might be the mushroom but felt that the burger just got tasteless the more I ate it.Shake Shack wasn't bad but it's also not a taste I would crave to come back and eat.

This is the first shake shack in southeast asia and im hyped!!!!! Coming from San Fransisco we do not have a shake shack here (odd i know) But I was so excited hearing that there was a shake shack in the new changi jewel.

Total time from start of wait to burger in the mouth 35 mins.  Can't complaint.  Other than at opening they are already short of peppers and pickle all else good.  Only issue is i would say they should stop the ordering when there are no seats as that will prevent people doing the hongkong style wait giving u the stare to finish your food fast!!!

amazing service. the waitresses looked after us so well including our 1 year old and dog!the restaurant is supposed to have robot service but we sat outside because it was a beautiful night. they had a promotion on crab and beer... so pretty well perfect. we ordered pepper crab but we ended up getting a chilli crab. i was still pretty good. we also got some crispy octopus. no what i was expecting but pretty nice. the fried rice we also ordered was pretty nice but expensive i thought at $18 for a small one. admittedly it did have crab in it. still i probably wouldn't order that again. overall a really enjoyable meal at a reasonable price for what we got
Fun place with great service. They have robot waiters (and regular waiters) and a VR machine. Good, cheap food. Recommended!

Heavenly Wang gets 5 stars for value and deliciousness. I ordered the laksa set: laksa, kaya butter toast and kopi. Everything was so good. I would have stopped by again if I had the chance.It was the first time I had laksa in Singapore and it was very delicious. The soup base is like a creamy curry soup. You might not want to wear white in case the noodles splash on you, I remember the noodles being a little firmer. The kaya butter toast was just as delicious. A lot of butter but it was okay because the hot coffee melts it down.Airport location was quiet and peaceful. Would definitely stop by again!

Breakfast in Changi airport after a red eye flight from the Maldives! Ahhh I love all the food in Singapore in my previous trip, I wish this one wasn't just a short 2 hour layover. But alas Heavenly Wang satisfy my local Singaporean food cravings. This shop also had the longest line so you know it's good! Ice Kopi, Mee Tai Mak the silver needle noodle with a dash of white pepper and of course peanut butter toast!  This location at T3 has bright and big windows so you can see all the airplanes as you enjoy your food.  Til next time!

Heavenly Wang is a godsend for people who have been away from Singapore for a while and crave for local food. It is usually very near the exit door after you leave the baggage carousel area.It is generally not as popular with the locals (think Ya Kun or ToastBox) so you will usually get a table. That is perfect. Order some local dishes -- kaya butter toast, kopi/teh, soft boiled eggs, mee siam, mee rebus, laksa, etc, and get a table and wait for the buzzer to vibrate. Pick up your food and back to table and tuck in. The food is decent or good if you have been away for a long time. I always will stop by for some food and kopi after a 24-hour or so journey. I do like the coffee though.

Came by for a quick snack after landing at Changi. Heavenly Wang is located post-security after customs and immigration!Ordered an Iced Milk Tea along with a Kaya Toast set. the iced milk tea was quite strong, smooth, without being too sweet. The Kaya toast was quite crispy and fresh with a stick of butter and jam inside along with a side of runny eggs for dipping!

16 hour flight and was exhausted. But hunger drove us to search for food before heading to the hotel. Went to the food court and my son took a tour to pick a restaurant he wanted to try. He picked Heavenly Wang. Had a line so must mean it's good right? Who knows as at an airport people sometimes choose convenience. Turned out pretty tasty. He had the chicken rendang set and I had the mee rebus set. The set came with a choice of drink and we selected barley instead of tea or coffee. He said his chicken rendang tasted good and it did look good. Not a huge portion but enough. My mee rebus wasn't to my taste and was different than the preparation I had growing up. Could be that it's a regional difference between Singapore and Malaysia. Not my fav but I was hungry so I ate it. Scoring higher as the place was better than I thought for airline terminal food and would eat there again.

Pretty decent spot for a quick breakfast outside T2 in Changi. Had the famed Kaya butter toast. Came out quick, could have done with a bit more butter. Overall good value for money, a solid 3.5 stars.

Couldn't help my self to stop when I saw the Nasi Lemak wrapped in banana leaves and it's cost me SGD5.20 with a bottle of mineral water. The chili sauce and anchovies plus peanuts were excellent but the fried fish was soggy. No half boiled egg nor cucumbers. Well, it's good enough to cure my craving for nasi lemak.

This place is fabulous! I flew through Singapore twice within two weeks and ate here both times. The food is really yummy and incredibly inexpensive. I got the Curry Chicken with white rice. Really good and very filling. Plus it's only 7.00 Singapore dollars ( $5.20 usd). Add to that that the staff is very nice and helpful. I will definitely eat here again every time fly into Singapore airport.

Located outside the baggage claim area in Terminal three. Great reasonably priced noodle soup offerings.  Like fast food but better.  Order and pay at the counter, and given a pager.We ordered #4&#5 soup noodle combos that came with toast and coffee or tea.  $6.50 Singapore dollars.  Lots of seating available.
Can't believe airport food can be this good:). Highly recommend this place.We ordered spicy soup bowl and bread n butter, both soooo good

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #B1-35, Changi City Point Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: A chain of cafes serving up Singaporean breakfast specialties. Simple honest and affordable food in a clean environment. I usually get the Kaya toast set with teh tarik. Comfort food at it's core is what this place is good for!

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #B1-35, Changi City Point Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: Nice outlet with lots of seats. Like the round tables that allows groups of 6 to gather around and have tea and rekindle their relationships and catch up on the latest gossip. Whenever I visit Ya Kun, I would definitely order their French Toast with Kaya and a good ol' cup of Kopi-c. The French Toast is well covered by the egg and toasted. Fragrance of eggs on the toast (my soft spot) keeps me coming back for more. It's not too oily and the accompanying Kaya for it makes it even more delectable. One other order that I love to make is the Steam Bread with Butter and Kaya. It comes in the Dim Sum steamer container and is kept piping hot. Have that with a cuppa Kopi-c hot or cold, never fails to put my mind at rest for the time I am feasting there.

address: 314 Bedok Road Bedok Shopping Complex Singapore 469478 Singapore
comment: Nice green curry, Papaya, Salad, pad Thai, Tom Yum fried rice. Real flavour from Thailand (all together 37 bucks)

Stumbled upon this chinese Restuarant which used to be a western restaurant. After checking out the menu, decided to visit here for family dinner. Turns out Chef Pung is a veteran with strong clientele following. Saw a local veteran actor patronising during our visit. The dishes were well-executed, elegant and reasonably priced. Portions are a tad small. Will return again.

Came here on a Monday 6pm.  Think that is probably the best time with not that many people.  All in all food was pretty good i must say.  There are certainly skills here worth paying for the extra as compared with the normal zi char stall.  Service weren't as horrible as i have read from google perhaps because they weren't too busy as yet.  Will be back with a bigger Troop.
If I could give them a negative rating I would. The food is so so but the service is the worst ever. Staff are unfriendly and unhelpful. Basically they just ignore you.

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-44 Changi City Point Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: This is a review of Pondok Kartika.  It has recently opened in Changi City Point Mall.As with any review I do for Indonesian restaurants, I can not review based on authenticity.  I can only review based on whether I enjoyed the food.Since, this is a new place.  It still has that feeling of new.  The ambiance is basic and functional without feeling sparse.I will note that it does get quite busy for lunch.  There can be a wait.  At least once, i was going to have lunch there but based on the expected wait decided otherwise.On the day I ate there, we were able to get in just before the lineup started.The staff is relatively friendly. They are also professional and polite.For the most part, I really enjoyed the food.Beef Satay - This is the only dish I did not enjoy.  There was something about the flavour of the beef that I did not personally like.  It may have simply been a thing of personal taste.tinyurl.com/9n6h7jsBeef Rendang - I enjoyed this.  I wouldn't have minded a bit more of  a kick.   But, I was able add a little.  There was a nice layering of flavours though.tinyurl.com/8trwajgRoast Chicken - I thought this was great.  The chicken was very moist. The skin added a lot of flavour.  Good all around roasted chicken.tinyurl.com/8uk289wOverall, this is a good option for lunch in the Changi Business Park area.  Once again, like most of the places there, it wouldn't make much sense to make a special trip to eat there.  But, definitely if you are already around, its a good lunch experience.

address: 86 East Coast Rd #01-01 Katong Square Singapore 428788 Singapore
comment: Just to be clear we are food purists who sneer at anything fusion. Having said that: Holy Cowabunga!!!! This place is freaking so good you will want to slap your mama and papa. Started out the otah appetizer, not a clue as to what the black buns were but they were delicious. Ready to just have just have twenty of these little bundles. Hubby has Peranakan Pulled Pork burger. The bun was pillowy and as someone who eats pulled pork from the American south, I would happily put this in front of any of my southern friends with the perfect assurance they will love it. For me I had the crawfish Kuay Tiao (wise rice noodle) with a side of achar.  The  dish was a perfect amalgamation of street style char kuay tiao with a luxurious flair with the crawfish addition. Finally dessert. Oh heaven wept. Pandas cake so soft hubs was afraid it may collapse. My Ondeh with durian was so soft and sublime. Warm pandan crepe filled with durian, top with cool ice cream. Heaven really wept!!!! Service was top notch too.So run don't walk to this gem!!!!

address: 86 East Coast Rd #01-01 Katong Square Singapore 428788 Singapore
comment: So bad. When you are located in the food haven of Katong, I really can't figure out why this place would bother serving food that is just utterly bad. When the pricing is $15 for a plate of fried kway teow or nonya fried rice, there better be a very good reason why you're charging this premium compared to all the amazing food outlets that are just a couple of steps from your door.We tried the chilli crab cake - not good and the fried mantou is so fried and tiny that it's more like a tiny biscuit. I am a huge fan of Ayam bua keluak (candle nut chicken) but their Ayam bua keluak burger while sounding promising on the menu, is a dreadful mess.  Don't bother with the Penang Hokkien Mee or the nonya fried rice either. Actually, don't bother coming at all.

address: 86 East Coast Rd #01-01 Katong Square Singapore 428788 Singapore
comment: Great variety of Peranakan food, whipped up using the freshest of ingredients. Enjoyed the Chap Chye, Ayam buah keluak, sambal stingray and laksa. Simply couldn't keep my hands off the sambal belachan. Aside from the ambience and furniture, the service was similarly top notch.

address: 86 East Coast Rd #01-01 Katong Square Singapore 428788 Singapore
comment: Decent food. I ordered the pork rice bowl. Filling, but with a fishy aftertaste. Atmosphere was very pleasant with polite staff. A bit pricy, but a good brunch destination. However, the restaurant is only a stones throw away from seemingly similar, but better options.

address: 86 East Coast Rd #01-01 Katong Square Singapore 428788 Singapore
comment: Very good breakfast selection and quality. Not a fan of the hollandaise sauce though. Fresh juice, fruit and eggs are very tasty. Always a couple interesting options on the specials board as well. Attached to the Hotel Indigo which is really nice.

address: 86 East Coast Rd #01-01 Katong Square Singapore 428788 Singapore
comment: The food was delicious, service attentive, and atmosphere beautiful. My family of 4 ate outside, and there was a lovely water fountain that my kids enjoyed while waiting for our meal. I love how early they're open for breakfast, great for tourists. We got eggs benedict, belgian waffles, kaya toast with dimsum, and a big kids' breakfast. The western fare was definitely better than the Asian stuff. (Dim sum was dry and lacked flavor, but everything else was awesome!) All that, plus pulled coffee and tea, made for a pretty pricey breakfast ($75!), so this could not possibly be a regular habit for us. But it was a lovely treat!

address: 86 East Coast Rd #01-01 Katong Square Singapore 428788 Singapore
comment: Not sure why the reviews are low. This is for breakfast only. The food is good, not that fast, but not ridiculously slow either. It gets really busy in there, and the staff could be more attentive. For example, I had to ask 4 different people for coffee, and got coffee after 20 minutes. That's pretty ridiculous. Other than that, the menu is pretty extensive and the food tastes good.

So House of Peranakan ain't too bad a place for Peranakan (what else) food. The food is pretty solid all round. Is it the best? Is it worth driving all the way to frankel for? Hmmm wellllll. Yes -- only because you are almost guaranteed seats in this quiet place. Decor:The place is kitschy and quaint (read: charmingly old skool). It's got all records and furniture and a clumsy grand piano near its doorway, no doubt previously used to great effect. Stepping inside, you'd doubtlessly feel transported into the 60s. Nay, 50s. Food:Overall, quite a number of stand outs. (1) bakwang kepiting soup. Now, I found the broth a little strange. Too much fried shallots. However, the crab meat and minced meat paste was fabulous, sitting on a crab shell. I enjoyed it greatly. My sis didn't. Ah well. Can't please everyone! $5 each person, minimum two people. (2) Ayam buah keluak. I genuinely loved the buah keluak!!!! I dug it out with my spoon and usually it's just the nutty earthy meat. But at this place, I believed they stuffed the nut with other spices and mixed the buah keluak meat with minced meat! In any cAse, it was sedap!!!! (3) sambal udang (prawns). Yummmmmmmm. (4) chili fries pomfret. Crispy and fresh. Reminds me of home. All in all, a good meal. My dad wanted chendol but they don't have it!! My dad was like "a Peranakan restaurant with no chendol?!?! sacrilegious!!!" Hahahahahahaha

address: 3014 Bedok Industrial Park E Singapore 489980 Singapore
comment: I hadn't had good steamboat for quite a while so so I decided to head to Century Village Eating House to get my fill of good ol charcoal steamboat with a couple of friends. We ordered the pomfret steamboat, foo yong omelette and frog with dried chilli.Dinner was great! The soup was good to drink as soon as the steamboat was placed on the table. The fish slices were fresh and we just had bowl after bowl after bowl of soup. The foo yong omelette was fantastic. We finished the first serving so quickly that we ordered a bigger portion to fill us up. The frog was also really good. Very meaty and tender.

This is pure magic. A simple uncle+auntie operation, and they make everything fresh, on the day you arrive to partake of said magic.Auntie stands behind the counter and does all the chopping, uncle does the service, and dishes out this amazing kway... the broth alone is worth the trip.So let's talk food - it's a real pig fest, and you'll want it all. Dua deng, sueh deng (large and small intestine - they clean them so well!), stomach, chia bak (lean meat). Then you ask for tau kee (beancurd skin), tau pok, and of course, giam chye. Then you sit, and wait patiently for uncle to deliver this magic to your table. And then you feast. And think about the next time you come back.

Hands down, the best prawn mee noodle house ever. Beach Road Prawn Noodle House quickly made it to the top of my list of must eat places in Singapore.Prawns are large and fresh, and are cut in a way such that it's relatively painless to slide the shells off the meat.
